function.name: list_files
function.description:
A directory listing tool:
Key Features:
- Lists files and directories
- Supports recursive listing up to a specified depth (depth: recursion depth, starting from 1)
- Supports file filtering
- Supports offset and limit for pagination (offset: start index, limit: max number of files)
- Returns detailed file info
- CRITICAL: filePath MUST be an absolute path, relative paths are not accepted
- CRITICAL: filePath must be returned before other fields.

depth.description: Recursion depth for directory listing (starting from 1)

limit.description: Maximum number of files to return, default is 200

function.name: search_file
function.description:
A versatile file search tool that supports wildcard pattern matching and recursive directory search. 
- Returns relative file paths. 
- Prefer this tool over list_files when you have specific file patterns to search for (e.g., "*.js", "test*.ts"). 
- This tool is optimized for pattern-based file search and excludes common directories like node_modules by default.
- CRITICAL: filePath MUST be an absolute path, relative paths are not accepted
- CRITICAL: pattern must be returned before other fields.

filePath.description: REQUIRED: Absolute path to existing directory. Must be accessible and exist in the workspace.

recursive.description: Set to "true" to search in subdirectories. Default is recursive search

caseSensitive.description: Set to "true" for case-sensitive search. Default is false (case-insensitive)

function.name: search_content
function.description:
Search for text content within files in a directory. 
    - Supports file type filtering, context lines, and pagination.
    - CRITICAL: directory MUST be an absolute path, relative paths are not accepted
    - CRITICAL: key must be returned before other fields.

directory.description: Absolute path of the directory to search in

contextLines.description: Number of context lines before and after each match (default: 3)

offset.description: Pagination offset - number of matches to skip (default: 0)

limit.description: Maximum number of matches to return (default: 50, max: 200)

caseSensitive.description: Set to "true" for case-sensitive search. Default is false (case-insensitive)

function.name: read_file
function.description:
A simple file reading tool:
Key Features:
- Reads file content by lines (recommended to read in small batches to avoid excessive token usage)
- UTF-8 encoding support
- Error handling for missing files
- Strict path handling with absolute paths only
- CRITICAL: filePath must be returned before other fields.

filePath.description: Path to read. Must be absolute

endLine.description: End line number (inclusive). Set to 0 to read entire file for small files. Recommended: 400 lines for better context.

function.name: replace_in_file
function.description:
Use this tool to propose a search and replace operation on an existing file.
The tool supports replacing multiple occurrences of old_str with new_str in the specified file. 
If you want to replace only ONE specific instance, you must ensure the old_str string uniquely identifies that instance.
CRITICAL REQUIREMENTS FOR USING THIS TOOL:

1. WHEN REPLACING A SPECIFIC INSTANCE: If you need to replace only one specific occurrence, ensure uniqueness:
   - Include AT LEAST 1-3 lines of context BEFORE the change point
   - Include AT LEAST 1-3 lines of context AFTER the change point
   - CRITICAL: Include all whitespace, indentation, blank lines, and surrounding code exactly as it appears in the file

2. VERIFICATION: Before using this tool:
   - Verify the old_str exists in the file
   - Ensure old_str is different from new_str
   - Use correct line endings according to the operating system
   - For deletion, use an empty string as new_str
   - CRITICAL: Do not add any extra wrapping characters, such as quotation marks ', before or after old_str.
   - CRITICAL: filePath must be returned before other fields, i.e., in streaming responses, always return the filePath field first, then the other fields.

3. USAGE TIPS:
   - For batch changes, use shorter old_str strings to match multiple instances
   - For specific changes, use more context to ensure uniqueness
   - Try to combine adjacent changes (within 20 lines) into a single call
   - Split non-adjacent changes (more than 20 lines apart) into separate calls
   - When replacing multiple instances in a file:
     * If instances are close together (within 20 lines), combine them in one call
     * If instances are far apart (>20 lines), split into multiple calls
     * Use minimal context for batch replacements to catch all adjacent instances

filePath.description: REQUIRED: Absolute file path to existing file. File must be accessible and exist in the workspace.

old_str.description: REQUIRED: Exact text to find in file. Must be unique and specific to avoid unintended matches. Will be validated against file content.

new_str.description: REQUIRED: Replacement text. MUST be different from old_str text. Cannot be identical to old_str parameter.

function.name: write_to_file
function.description:
A file creation tool for VS Code:
        Key Features:
        - Always specify the file path (filePath) before writing content. The file path is the basis for all subsequent operations.
        - Primarily used for creating new files, with automatic creation of parent directories if they do not exist.
        - Opens the file in the editor after writing, using proper encoding.
        - If you need to modify the content of an existing file, prefer using the replace_in_file tool instead.
        - Preserves original line endings and formatting.
        - CRITICAL: filePath MUST be an absolute path; relative paths are not accepted.
        - CRITICAL: Since this operation will overwrite the file, you must ensure that it is safe to overwrite the current content of the file before proceeding.
        - CRITICAL: filePath must be returned before content, i.e., in streaming responses, always return the filePath field first, then the content field.
        - CRITICAL: Both filePath and content parameters must be provided; neither can be omitted.

filePath.description: Target file absolute path. Parent directories will be created if needed.

content.description: Content to write. For streaming mode, represents incremental content

function.name: execute_command
function.description:
VS Code Command Execution Assistant:
        Key Features:
        - Execute system commands directly, adapting to the user's OS and shell.  
        - Always verify the working directory first(prepend 'cd /path && ' if needed).  
        - Explain each command's purpose and warn about risks.  
        - Support complex commands and provide cross- platform alternatives.
        - CRITICAL: Commands that operate on files outside the current workspace require user approval for security.

command.description: The CLI command to execute. Must be valid for the current OS and free of harmful instructions.

requires_approval.description:
Set to true if the command requires user approval. Required for: destructive operations, 
                commands operating outside workspace boundaries, or potentially risky operations. 
                Set to false for safe operations within workspace.

                      â€¢ Tool: mcp_resolve-library-id
     
                        Description: Resolves a package/product name to a Context7-compatible library ID and returns a list of matching libraries.

You MUST call this function before 'get-library-docs' to obtain a valid Context7-compatible library ID UNLESS the user explicitly provides a library ID in the format '/org/project' or '/org/project/version' in their query.

Selection Process:
1. Analyze the query to understand what library/package the user is looking for
2. Return the most relevant match based on:
- Name similarity to the query (exact matches prioritized)
- Description relevance to the query's intent
- Documentation coverage (prioritize libraries with higher Code Snippet counts)
- Trust score (consider libraries with scores of 7-10 more authoritative)

Response Format:
- Return the selected library ID in a clearly marked section
- Provide a brief explanation for why this library was chosen
- If multiple good matches exist, acknowledge this but proceed with the most relevant one
- If no good matches exist, clearly state this and suggest query refinements

For ambiguous queries, request clarification before proceeding with a best-guess match.
     
                        Required Arguments: {"type":"object","properties":{"libraryName":{"type":"string","description":"Library name to search for and retrieve a Context7-compatible library ID."}},"required":["libraryName"],"additionalProperties":false,"$schema":"http://json-schema.org/draft-07/schema#"}

You must call 'resolve-library-id' first to obtain the exact Context7-compatible library ID required to use this tool, UNLESS the user explicitly provides a library ID in the format '/org/project' or '/org/project/version' in their query.

                      â€¢ Tool: mcp_sequentialthinking
     
                        Description: A detailed tool for dynamic and reflective problem-solving through thoughts.
This tool helps analyze problems through a flexible thinking process that can adapt and evolve.
Each thought can build on, question, or revise previous insights as understanding deepens.

When to use this tool:
- Breaking down complex problems into steps
- Planning and design with room for revision
- Analysis that might need course correction
- Problems where the full scope might not be clear initially
- Problems that require a multi-step solution
- Tasks that need to maintain context over multiple steps
- Situations where irrelevant information needs to be filtered out

Key features:
- You can adjust total_thoughts up or down as you progress
- You can question or revise previous thoughts
- You can add more thoughts even after reaching what seemed like the end
- You can express uncertainty and explore alternative approaches
- Not every thought needs to build linearly - you can branch or backtrack
- Generates a solution hypothesis
- Verifies the hypothesis based on the Chain of Thought steps
- Repeats the process until satisfied
- Provides a correct answer

Parameters explained:
- thought: Your current thinking step, which can include:
* Regular analytical steps
* Revisions of previous thoughts
* Questions about previous decisions
* Realizations about needing more analysis
* Changes in approach
* Hypothesis generation
* Hypothesis verification
- next_thought_needed: True if you need more thinking, even if at what seemed like the end
- thought_number: Current number in sequence (can go beyond initial total if needed)
- total_thoughts: Current estimate of thoughts needed (can be adjusted up/down)
- is_revision: A boolean indicating if this thought revises previous thinking
- revises_thought: If is_revision is true, which thought number is being reconsidered
- branch_from_thought: If branching, which thought number is the branching point
- branch_id: Identifier for the current branch (if any)
- needs_more_thoughts: If reaching end but realizing more thoughts needed

You should:
1. Start with an initial estimate of needed thoughts, but be ready to adjust
2. Feel free to question or revise previous thoughts
3. Don't hesitate to add more thoughts if needed, even at the "end"
4. Express uncertainty when present
5. Mark thoughts that revise previous thinking or branch into new paths
6. Ignore information that is irrelevant to the current step
7. Generate a solution hypothesis when appropriate
8. Verify the hypothesis based on the Chain of Thought steps
9. Repeat the process until satisfied with the solution
10. Provide a single, ideally correct answer as the final output
11. Only set next_thought_needed to false when truly done and a satisfactory answer is reached
     
                        Required Arguments: {"type":"object","properties":{"thought":{"type":"string","description":"Your current thinking step"},"nextThoughtNeeded":{"type":"boolean","description":"Whether another thought step is needed"},"thoughtNumber":{"type":"integer","description":"Current thought number","minimum":1},"totalThoughts":{"type":"integer","description":"Estimated total thoughts needed","minimum":1},"isRevision":{"type":"boolean","description":"Whether this revises previous thinking"},"revisesThought":{"type":"integer","description":"Which thought is being reconsidered","minimum":1},"branchFromThought":{"type":"integer","description":"Branching point thought number","minimum":1},"branchId":{"type":"string","description":"Branch identifier"},"needsMoreThoughts":{"type":"boolean","description":"If more thoughts are needed"}},"required":["thought","nextThoughtNeeded","thoughtNumber","totalThoughts"]}
